Update on FAST RECYCLER STACKING
Update on
FAST RECYCLER
STACKING
page.normal_text:
Chandra Bhat, Brian Chase, Bill Foster, Hyejoo Kang, Jim Maclachlan, Kiyomi Seiya, Phillip Varghese, Dave Wildman
Chandra Bhat, Brian Chase,
Bill Foster, Hyejoo Kang, Jim Maclachlan,
Kiyomi Seiya, Phillip Varghese, Dave Wildman

page.title:
Fast Recycler Stacking
Fast Recycler Stacking
page.enlisting:
• Method of longitudinal stacking – Increases charge density in Booster batches by – May allow more batches stacked in MI – Will allow early tests of MI at higher beam currents • Uses broadband “Arbitrary Waveform” RF system – Exists in RR; planned for longitudinal dampers in MI • Advantages WRT Slip Stacking: – No emittance growth (in principle) – No problems with Beam Loading (debunched beams) • Method of longitudinal stacking
• Method of longitudinal stacking
– Increases charge density in Booster batches by
– Increases charge density in Booster batches by
– May allow more batches stacked in MI – Will allow early tests of MI at higher beam currents • Uses broadband “Arbitrary Waveform” RF system – Exists in RR; planned for longitudinal dampers in MI

page.title:
First Tests in Recycler
First Tests in Recycler
page.enlisting:
• Recycler already has 2000V Arbitrary Waveform RF system, with controls • Recycler does not have extraneous cavities (2.5 MHz, 7.5 MHz and 53 MHz) which might resonate up (“beam loading”) and destroy the beam RF structure. 1. Debunch beam in MI 2. Compress the beam in Recycler 3. Transfer back to MI 4. Rebunch and Accelerate (…not done) • Recycler already has 2000V Arbitrary Waveform RF system, with controls
• Recycler already has 2000V Arbitrary
Waveform RF system, with controls
• Recycler does not have extraneous cavities (2.5 MHz, 7.5 MHz and 53 MHz) which might resonate up (“beam loading”) and destroy the beam RF structure.
• Recycler does not have extraneous cavities
(2.5 MHz, 7.5 MHz and 53 MHz) which
might resonate up (“beam loading”) and
destroy the beam RF structure.
1. Debunch beam in MI 2. Compress the beam in Recycler 3. Transfer back to MI 4. Rebunch and Accelerate (…not done)
